awd_titl_txt: Do connections persist? A pilot study investigating the lasting impact of a physics course designed to facilitate connections with biology.
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will study the effectiveness of new approaches for teaching physics to future life scientists and medical professionals, in order to support the use and improvement of these new curricula nationwide. These new, active learning-based physics courses have been developed in response to calls by life science and medical professional associations for introductory physics courses that help students apply the physical sciences to the life sciences. With several such courses having been developed recently, and with roughly 300,000 undergraduates graduating each year with majors in the life sciences and health professions nationwide, it is important to find out whether and how these physics courses support students in their chosen fields.

The goal of this research project is to address two questions: (1) Do introductory physics for life sciences (IPLS) students demonstrate a greater ability to leverage physics competencies in their later biology coursework, compared to their peers who have taken no physics or traditional introductory physics? If so, in what ways? (2) Do IPLS students view physics as more relevant and connected to their biology and chemistry coursework, compared with their peers? If so, in what ways? This longitudinal study will analyze interviews, surveys of students, and students' written work on tasks in their intermediate and advanced biology courses. From these data, this project will develop an understanding of how biology students draw upon their physics knowledge and skills, and whether and how IPLS courses support them differently than traditional physics courses do. As such a longitudinal study has not previously been done, this project is important because it lays the groundwork for future large-scale assessment. In addition, the project will develop intermediate and advanced biology tasks with connections to physics, which will be disseminated for both instructional use and for further research.

por.por_cntn:
Biology and medicine have become increasingly quantitative and technological fields, benefiting from the work of scientists and engineers in a wide range of disciplines. Professional societies for biologists and medical professionals have increasingly identified the need for solid grounding in the physical sciences and quantitative skills. Recently, reformed physics courses, sometimes called Introductory Physics for the Life Sciences (IPLS) courses, have been designed to help life science and pre-health undergraduates build connections between the physics in the course and their study and work in the life sciences.

To determine whether these IPLS courses indeed help students develop lasting skill at using physics and quantitative skills to analyze biological situations, we compared student work from three groups of students: those who took such IPLS courses, those who took a non-IPLS introductory physics course at the same level, and those who took no undergraduate physics. To compare the skills of these groups, we designed and gave tasks to students in a senior biology capstone course, in which some students had taken physics up to two years earlier, including those who were taking a physics course concurrently. We found that students from the IPLS physics course were better able than their peers without the IPLS course to use physics and quantitative methods to analyze biological problems, even two years after completing the course.

            We also surveyed students on their perceptions of the value of physics and math to the life sciences, and found that those perceptions were improved in those who had taken the IPLS course. We also found that the improved perceptions were maintained for at least a year after taking the course (the length of time we were able to follow students in this study). Because these students had not taken any more physics courses after the ILPS course, our findings suggest that whatever later experiences they had had in life science coursework or research did not diminish the positive perceptions developed in the IPLS course.

            The Intellectual Merit of this work is that we provided the first evidence that IPLS courses indeed lead to improved student ability to use physics in analyzing biological situations, improvements which last for as much as two years. We also showed that improved student perceptions of the value of physics to the life sciences also last for at least a year after the conclusion of the course. As we carried out this study at a small liberal arts college, only about 75 students completed any given task or survey; future studies at larger institutions and universities would be valuable to confirm this finding.

            The Broader Impacts of this work are to help improve the education of future life science and health professionals. Improving the physical sciences preparation of these students has been called for by life science and medical professional societies (see reports "Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education" and "Scientific Foundations for Future Physicians"). Demonstrating that IPLS courses may lead to improved attitudes and improved skill in using physics and quantitative competencies gives programs more information about how to best educate their students, leading to a better prepared workforce.
